                                                    Hope Street

Phase 1)                 210        +        330                   or          420       +           20
                          2                   1                                 2                     1
                         105                 330                               210                   20

             FEHR & PEERS

   201 Santa Monica Boulevard, Suite 500

      Santa Monica, California 90401

             Ref: SM09-2334
Cornfield Arroyo/Seco Specific Plan Model Validation Report
July 2009



1. INTRODUCTION
Fehr & Peers has developed a sub-area travel demand model for the Cornfield/Arroyo Seco Specific Plan
(CASP). This model was developed by modifying the 2008 Regional Transportation Plan (RTP) travel
demand forecasting (TDF) model maintained by the Southern California Association of Governments
(SCAG). The sub-area model provides additional land use and roadway network detail within the project
study area roughly bounded by Cypress Avenue to the north, SR 101 to the south, SR 110 to the west,
and Daly Street to the east. This report documents the development, calibration and validation of the
sub-area travel demand model, including the sources of data used to develop key model inputs, and
summarizes how well the sub-area model performs against validation thresholds established by Caltrans.

BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE
The intent of developing a sub-area model for CASP was to create a travel model that can be used as a
tool in the evaluation of land use scenarios and transportation system alternatives. The model provides
the ability to evaluate the transportation system, use performance indicators for land use and
transportation alternatives, provide information on regional pass through traffic versus locally generated
trips and provide graphical displays of these results. In essence the travel forecasts will be used to
estimate the effectiveness of the proposed specific plan policies on the transportation system.

The SCAG regional model provides a starting point for creating a detailed, locally valid sub-area model to
which future roadway improvements and land use assumptions can be added. Starting with a regionally
valid model ensures the sub-area model captures regional traffic flow patterns and transit ridership while
the additional detail allows the sub-area model to capture local traffic patterns. The sub-area model can
then be used to develop traffic volume forecasts to evaluate the transportation improvements needed to
accommodate the increases in land use and densities associated with the CASP. Having a locally valid
sub-area model is a critical step in ensuring a high level of confidence in these resulting traffic volume
forecasts.

OVERVIEW OF MODEL
The sub-area model for CASP was developed using the TransCAD Version 4.8 Build 500 modeling
software. The model has been designed to produce AM and PM peak period vehicle and transit flows on
roadway and transit facilities within the project study area based on comprehensive land use and
socioeconomic data (SED). The model utilizes a typical four-step process consisting of trip generation,
trip distribution, modal split, and assignment. The model components including key model inputs and
outputs are summarized on Figure 1. Additional detail regarding the 2008 RTP Model can be obtained in
User's Guide for the SACG Planning Model (Southern California Association of Governments, June,
2008). The roadway and transit networks along with the traffic analysis zone (TAZ) structure were
modified to ensure the model produced traffic forecasts that reasonably resemble observed traffic counts
obtained in the project study area in 2009.

Following validation of base year 2009 forecasts, the modifications to the base year 2008 RTP Model will
be applied to the future year model to produce forecasts of future vehicle and transit flows in the project
study area. These forecasts would then be used in the identification of system deficiencies and the
development of transportation improvements needed to accommodate the increases in land use and
densities associated with CASP.

2. SUB-AREA MODEL DEVELOPMENT
To improve the model's forecasting ability and to be consistent with the land use data provided by ARUP,
an increased level of detail was added to the 2008 RTP model roadway network, transit network, and
TAZ structure. Substantial modifications were made within the project study area that were necessary to
validate the base year sub-area model to traffic counts collected in 2009. Outside the project study area,
the zone system and model networks were modified to a lesser degree in order to model the traffic and
transit flows in and out of the project study area more accurately. Adjacent TAZs were primarily modified
while TAZs further away became become gradually less detailed.

This section summarizes the roadway network, transit network, and TAZ structure changes made to the
base year 2008 RTP Model.

ROADWAY NETWORK
As shown in Figure 2, the base year 2008 RTP model roadway network was modified to include all
project arterial and collector roadways in order to facilitate the proper assignment of vehicles through the
project study intersections. Additionally, the roadway network was reviewed to ensure each roadway's
facility type, free-flow speed, and number of lanes matched data observed in aerial photography and field
observations.

TRANSIT NETWORK
The base year 2008 RTP model transit network was reviewed to ensure all existing transit routes and
stops were present and correctly coded in the model due to the project's proximity to Union Station and
the likelihood that patrons utilize and will continue to utilize the nearby transit service to access the project
study area.

TAZ STRUCTURE
The 2008 RTP model divides the project study area into four non-overlapping TAZs connected to the
model roadway and transit networks by centroid connectors. The existing TAZ structure was then
disaggregated in order to forecast traffic volumes for intersection-level analysis. Following the
disaggregation of the TAZs, centroid connectors were reconnected at mid-block locations in order to
facilitate the flow of traffic onto major arterials. The existing four SCAG TAZs were disaggregated into a
total of 91 TAZs (each with their own centroid connector) and connected at mid-block locations to improve
the loading of vehicle and transit trips to the roadway and transit networks. This also allows for the
incorporation of future land use patterns in areas that are expected to experience significant changes. As
shown in Figure 3, the four existing TAZs were typically split along major roadways, rail lines, and
physical/man made boundaries.

TAZs outside the project study area were disaggregated from 22 adjacent TAZs into 55 TAZs. This will
aid the modeling of traffic and transit flows into and out of the project study area. As with the project
study area TAZs, each TAZ centroid connector was inspected and modified to connect at mid-block
locations.

Since TAZs are used to tabulate demographic and employment data, the model SED file was then
modified by reallocating demographic and employment assumptions from the original 26 TAZs in and
adjacent to the project study area to the 146 new TAZs. The data for each new CASP TAZ was allocated
from its corresponding SCAG TAZ based on aerial photography and field observations into the following
categories.

       Population

       Households

             o   By size

             o   By head of household age

             o   By number of workers

             o   By income

       Workers

             o   By Income level (low, medium and high)

       School Enrollment

       Total Employment

             o   By income level (low, medium and high)

             o   By type (agricultural, construction, manufacturing, wholesale, retail, transportation,
                 information services, financial/real estate, professional, educational, arts/entertainment,
                 other services, public administration)

Base year demographic and employment assumptions for the project study area are shown in Table 1.


                                           TABLE 1
                      BASE YEAR DEMOGRAPHIC AND EMPLOYMENT ASSUMPTIONS



                              Category                                Quantity


                              Population                               14,089


                             Households                                3,660


                                 Jobs                                  10,154


                               Students                                4,968




                                                                                                          6
Cornfield Arroyo/Seco Specific Plan Model Validation Report
July 2009



3. SUB-AREA MODEL VALIDATION
Following the modification of the roadway network, transit network, and TAZ structure, the sub-area
model was validated to ensure the model replicated 2009 traffic conditions and would respond to changes
in the built environment. The validation process involved the calibration of model parameters in the land
use and roadway network files. The parameters were iteratively adjusted until the model attained
validation criteria established by Caltrans. Two types of model validation were performed  static
validation and dynamic validation. The validation procedures and results are summarized below.

STATIC VALIDATION
The most critical static measurement of the accuracy of any travel model is the degree to which it can
approximate actual traffic counts in the base year. For a model to be considered accurate and appropriate
for use in traffic forecasting, it must replicate actual conditions to within a certain level of accuracy.

A sub-area validation was performed on the base year model to ensure the model produces traffic
forecasts that reasonably resemble observed traffic counts obtained in the project study area in 2009.
Traffic forecasting models are typically calibrated by adjusting model parameters until they are validated
by applying a set of criteria that compare model link volumes to actual counts. For the CASP, land use
and roadway network modifications such as adjusting roadway speeds and capacities were made to the
sub-area model and the resulting roadway link volumes were compared to roughly 184 intersection
approach and departure volumes derived from turning movement counts collected in March 2009, 23
roadways segments counts collected in October 2008, and four freeway mainline volumes factored to
represent 2009 conditions. Model volumes were also compared to traffic counts along 10 model
validation screenlines, as shown in Figure 4.

Caltrans has established guidelines for determining whether a model is valid and acceptable for
forecasting future year traffic volumes. The sub-area validation results were compared to the following
validation thresholds discussed in Travel Forecasting Guidelines (California Department of
Transportation, November, 1992):

       The two-way sum of the volumes on all roadway links for which counts are available should be
        within 10 percent of the counts.

       All of the roadway screenlines should be within the maximum desirable deviation of at least 75
        percent.

       At least 75 percent of the roadway links for which counts are available should be within the
        maximum desirable deviation, which ranges from approximately 15 to 60 percent depending on
        total volume (the larger the volume, the less deviation is permitted).

       The correlation coefficient between the actual ground counts and the estimated traffic volumes
        should be greater than 88 percent.

Although not stated in the Caltrans standards, an additional Fehr & Peers validation guideline was applied
to the CASP sub-area model:

       The percent root mean square (RMSE) should not exceed 40 percent.

The results for AM and PM peak hour conditions are summarized in Table 1 below, while the detailed
spreadsheets are presented in Appendix A.



                                                                                                        7
            N
    NOT TO SCALE




                                                                                                     Legend
                                                                                                         Model Validation Screenlines
                                                                                                         CASP Boundary
                                                                                                         Modified Roadway Network




                                                                                                        MODEL VALIDATION SCREENLINES
July 24, 2009    SP

                                                                                                                               FIGURE 4
Cornfield Arroyo/Seco Specific Plan Model Validation Report
July 2009




                                             TABLE 2
                           RESULTS OF PEAK HOUR STATIC MODEL VALIDATION



                                                                                        Model Results
                                                                Criterion for
                   Validation Statistic
                                                                Acceptance
                                                                                      AM             PM


      % of Links within Caltrans Standard Deviations                75%              77%            76%


   % of Screenlines within Caltrans Standard Deviations            100%              100%          100%


             2-way Sum of All Links Counted                     Within 10%           <1%            <1%

                  Correlation Coefficient                     Greater than 88%       95%            96%


                          RMSE                                  40% or less          39%            39%


As shown in Table 2, the CASP sub-area model meets or exceeds the guidelines for model accuracy in
the AM and PM peak hours. Therefore, the base year CASP sub-area model is considered to be valid to
2009 traffic counts and appropriate for use in traffic forecasting. Additionally, the two-way sum of all links
counted being within 1% of observed traffic counts indicates the magnitude of trips in the study area is
appropriate, while validating along all screenlines indicates the directionality of trips in the study area is
appropriate.

DYNAMIC VALIDATION
The traditional approach to the validation of travel demand models is to compare the roadway segment
volumes for the model's base year to actual traffic counts collected in the same year. This approach
provides information on a model's ability to reproduce a static condition. However, models are seldom
used for static applications; by far the most common use of models is to forecast how a change in inputs
would result in a change in traffic conditions. Therefore, another test of a model's accuracy would focus
on the model's ability to predict realistic differences in outputs as inputs are changed; in other words,
"dynamic" validation rather than static validation.

Dynamic validation determines a model's sensitivity to changes in land uses and/or the transportation
system. These tests are recommended in Model Validation and Reasonableness Checking Manual
(Travel Model Improvement Program, FHWA, 1997). The results of dynamic validation tests are
inspected for reasonableness in the direction and magnitude of the changes.

Since the project evaluates a series of land use changes and how they affect the local transportation
system, the following tests were conducted on the CASP sub-area model for AM and PM peak hour
conditions.



                                                                                                            9
Cornfield Arroyo/Seco Specific Plan Model Validation Report
July 2009




       Add a new link
       Delete a link
       Add 200 jobs to a TAZ
       Add 50 jobs to a TAZ
       Add 180 households to a TAZ
       Add 20 households to a TAZ

For the dynamic tests, the AM and PM peak hour traffic forecasts were reviewed across a screenline to
verify whether the volumes changed in the appropriate direction and magnitude. As shown in
Appendix B, when a parallel link is added to the roadway network traffic volumes shift from adjacent
parallel routes to the added link and the overall screenline volume generally increases. When a parallel
link is removed, traffic volumes shift to the parallel routes and the overall screenline volume decreases.
When jobs and households are added to the model, the increase in vehicle trips is reasonable and the
average per unit vehicle trip increase for jobs and households remains relatively constant across time
periods and at various magnitudes.

Overall, the dynamic validation results suggest that the model will perform reasonably for future scenario
forecasting.
